titleproper.value: Guide to the Sanford J. Rosen Legal Files on Alger Hiss <num>TAM.736</num>

author.value: Collection processed by Amy C. Vo

corpname.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

unittitle.value: Sanford J. Rosen Legal Files on Alger Hiss

extent.value: in 1 record carton and 1 half manuscript box.

abstract.value: Sanford Jay Rosen is a founding and senior partner at Rosen Bien Galvan & Grunfeld LLP in San Francisco, California, where he concentrates his practice on constitutional and civil rights law, employment law, consumer law, complex commercial litigation, and litigation involving attorneys. He was working for the American Civil Liberties Union during the time he was Alger Hiss' attorney in the 1972 <emph render="italic">Hiss et al. v. Hampton et al.</emph> case. The plaintiffs' annuity applications were denied due to certain provisions of the "Hiss Act." Rosen's papers relate to his time as Alger Hiss' lawyer during this 1972 case to restore his federal pension. Materials include drafts and research for memos, correspondence, and legal research, as well as files related to Alger Hiss' friendship with Mr. Rosen.

p.value: Identification of item, date; Sanford J. Rosen Legal Files on Alger Hiss; TAM 736; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.
Donated by Sanford Jay Rosen, September 2018. The accession number associated with this gift is 2019.002.

Sanford Jay Rosen is a founding and senior partner at Rosen Bien Galvan & Grunfeld LLP in San Francisco, California, where he concentrates his practice on constitutional and civil rights law, employment law, consumer law, complex commercial litigation, and litigation involving attorneys. He was working for the American Civil Liberties Union during the time he was Alger Hiss' attorney in the 1972 <emph render="italic">Hiss et al. v. Hampton et al.</emph> case.

Former employees of the federal government, plaintiffs in the <emph render="italic">Hiss v. Hampton</emph> case had applied for annuities under the Civil Service Retirement Act. Their applications were denied by the Civil Service Commission due to certain provisions of the "Hiss Act." In the <emph render="italic">Hiss v. Hampton</emph> case, Sanford J. Rosen won a dispositive summary judgment motion that declared the Hiss Act an unconstitutional ex post facto law.
